commentBody: Very fun! It seemed quick to me, but several of the longer phrases were very natural to my ear so maybe I was just on the right wavelength tonight.
My deep condolences to Ms. Baik on the loss of her friend, lab partner, and puzzle partner. I'm sure he would have been thrilled to see your published puzzle.
Seemed a bit easier than most Fridays.
Thoroughly enjoying working this one. Thank you

Two nice grid spanning triple stacks and some fresh answers and clever clues made this one a quick delight.  Not the hardest Friday ever, but plenty of fun.  
Sadly, CDSLOTs are becoming a thing of the past.

I came here to share how much I enjoyed this puzzle and its fresh grid-spanning stacks. But perhaps the best part of today's entry is Adrianne Baik's beautiful contructor notes and the absolute gut punch at the end. Somewhere Arjun is smiling over this fabulous debut. I so look forward to the next puzzle.

Lovely puzzle and a beautiful tribute to your friend. I’m so sorry for your loss, Ms. Baik, especially as you are so young, but I know for sure Arjun would be extremely proud of you. Please keep making puzzles!
A lighter but still very enjoyable Friday. Loved the triple stacks. A great debut with a heartfelt story from the creator to go along with it.

I'm sure Arjun would be watching over, thrilled by Ms. Baik's accomplishment. Looking forward to more puzzles in the future.

From Gen Z's point of view, I suppose 37A is indeed a "retro" tech. I feel old...

This had a nice grid and fill, with a few nice clues. But this was too easy for a Friday.

5/10.

best debut and constructor note of the year by far, in my opinion.  not many people around me took my new "frivolous" crossword hobby seriously when i started 4.5 years ago besides my crush (soon to be fiance) and my best friend in college. i remember late nights idling away at my computer without any mentorship or guidance until i hit on a mario bros theme set i really liked. i sent it in on a whim after everyone had gone to bed after mom's birthday, out of view, not thinking much of it. the one thing i remember was telling the few people who believed in me that i was waiting for their rejection. but then it never came. 

there's something special about young people, like you and i, finding pride and dignity and passion through creative pursuits, and the truly priceless life that is injected into them by great people like arjun. enjoy the day, adrienne. let arjun's playful, persistent and abundant love guide you to great things in life.
What a delicious double triple stack with little glue. Congratulations Adrianne!
Do I detect a subtle mini theme with 17 and 44 across?
That was most satisfying. Thanks, Adrianne!

Wow what a moving story and an excellent debut. I love long spanners and these were great, and not a lot of junky fill to get there. My only constructive criticism, for the editors as much as the constructor, is when you have long spanners, the down clues should be a bit more challenging. I filled them in so quickly I didn’t have enough time to chew on the across ones. Last nit—stop me if I am wrong—that’s a joke, not a pun. A pun should be a play on words or a double meaning. I don’t think this qualifies.

Nice puzzle, although I agree with those who say it's a bit too easy for a Friday.
One quibble:  The cluing for 39D may be an amusing play on words, but it is not a pun.
This was a fine, well-constructed Friday puzzle that I found definitely easier than I would prefer.

I am greatly impressed, Ms Baik, both in your skill as a constructor (and at such a tender age) AND in your choice of Chemistry as a major.

I LOL'd at your comment about solving puzzles while waiting in organic lab.  That's exactly how I remember organic lab.  A few interesting seconds followed by hours of boredom.  ("Reflux, but not too actively, for the next 72 hours.")

And to lose a friend at such an age much have been tragic.

When you get to Physical Chemistry you'll find it the single most rewarding class you've ever taken.  I am not at all biased because that was my primary teaching responsibility.
Amazing debut. A fresh voice and a unique solving experience.
Easy but clever and satisfying fill by a brilliant young college student. Very sad that her lab partner did not live to see this. https://www.hmc.edu/in-memoriam/arjun-vattipalli-27/
I had a lot of fun with this puzzle! Congrats Adrianne on making it to the NYTs, and thanks for sharing your story!

YES!

Greenland is Danish.  

Sing it out to all the heavens above and the earth below and the water over there somewhere.

Why some of us think we should put our grubby paws on it, I'll never understand.

This seemed like a younger, hipper puzzle than most Fridays, and my only difficulty was (ahem) the generation gap.  

Favorite clue: "Request by those under 21."

Looks like you've got a long haul case of the puzzle bug, Adrianne, and I'm sure we'll be seeing your name again.  In the meantime, thank you for this one!

Ms. Baik, nice grit and grace pushing through figuring out such a complex puzzle and the loss of a friend. 

I struggled with somethings with this puzzle, generation gap is a great way of putting it as I saw someone else comment. My other struggle was that usually when I am struggling with a clue, especially in a foreign language or baseball or political my go to for help was my boyfriend who speaks 3 languages, is very good at politics and history and baseball. However, after almost 13 years together we broke it off last weekend. Uggh
I loved and adored this pizzle! Truly felt like a meeting of the minds with our dear puzzle creator. Thanks so much for your good work!

Great debut, Adrianne!  So happy Arjun inspired you to create this fun and clever puzzle. Looking forward to the next one. 

Deb, I totally said, “I can’t hear you,” out loud after 3D!
In case no one has already pointed it out, Jeanette Rankin was the sole member of Congress to vote against the declaration of WAR on Japan in 1941.
An actual no silly gimmick crossword! Must've slipped through (and I really enjoyed it).
Nice debut

O man I spent the lion's share of my time filling
in the southern cross-spanners!

Indice pour 52 à travers très insaisissable.

Aye Captain Adrianne, 'tain't bad, 'tain't bad at all.

Rêves de la lune sur la mer 🌘⛵

A poignant story. It reminds me of a few coworkers of mine who have died suddenly over the years.

I’m also impressed that it sounds like you constructed the bulk of this within a 24-hour period. It was a different era, but when I was actively constructing (and even getting a few published) the process usually took me much (MUCH) longer. Great debut. Bravo!
Really enjoyed this puzzle! Thank you and well done!
Great puzzle. Flowed through the top half pretty smoothly while the bottom half took some time to tease out.
Great puzzle. Challenging but fair. Really solid!

Gosh, really appreciated this clean solve after a Thursday headscratcher!

Bonus: 
When was the last time a sea of open spaces filled so willimgly? Usually, it feels like "The Floor is Lava" with no footholds, but this was easy like a Sunday morning. 

No, not sculpting a bust of Lionel Richie - it's not words I'm looking for, just gold stars, Cap'n.

Sometimes I lament the demise of crosswordese, yet, not enough to bail on fussfree and fun solves like this gem.

Happy weekend, amigos!
I loved this debut because it was so approachable. I’m sorry for your and the whole Harvey Mudd’s loss. Thank you, Adrianne.
I'm glad Arjun continues to inspire you, Adrianne. This is a beautiful debut. I study chemistry too, just from across the seas. I wish your lab, and crossword, partner a peaceful rest.
Thank you for this wonderful puzzle, and I send my deepest condolences to you on the loss of your friend. I'm honored that you shared his story with us, and I'm sending you much peace and compassion.

Congratulations on this delightful debut, Adrianne! Thank you for your puzzle and for generously sharing how it came to be. A lovely way to honor Arjun’s memory. This is a diverse, thoughtful, and compassionate community of solvers and constructors, most of whom I’m sure will appreciate your creativity and poignant story.

Does anyone else have Taylor Swift going through their head right now? No? Well, I'm no Swiftie, but I have a little ear worm that begging to be shared. https://youtu.be/nfWlot6h_JM?si=LD434mh3kjZUDkUA I loved this puzzle. Was it too easy for a Friday? Probably. But the answers and clues were so fresh. Like Deb, I thought the answer to 45D should have been, "Hey, Boomer, buy me a beer," but that didn't fit. I was surprised to see references to old tech, and I'm not just talking about the FLIP PHONE. For 46A I thought of SiriusXM, Bluetooth, GPS, USB, everything except CDSLOT. Do new cars still come with those? I thought BARNES & Noble was on its way out, but apparently it's been making a comeback. I'll bet a lot of folks filled in His for 55D, but fortunately, I checked myself, only filling in the H until I had enough from the other entries to know it was HER. Loved seeing both 17A EVERY VOTE COUNTS and 44A DANISH in the same puzzle. Not so subliminal message?
rent and moons are sketch... very good puzzle otherwise

When I first saw the multiple intimidating spanners I thought I was done for. However, in the end I managed to fill the grid in Wednesday time without any lookups. In fact, the solve took only several minutes longer than this week's overly tough Monday (which requited three Googles). So... This probably seemed like a Monday to American solvers? And possibly all native speakers?

CHEATS IN was new to me, of course. Sport lingo, for almost any sport, and in any language, will never ceases to confuse me. My wife watches a lot of football (soccer), and I often ask her what the stuff the commentators are saying actually means. To me it sounds vaguely Polish, but I understand very little. The only sport I'm fluent in, in both English and Polish, is climbing. Slopers (Pol. oblaki), crimps (krawądki), slabs (połogi), fig fours, dead points, campusing, Houdini swaps, Gastons, barn doors, flags - all that means something to me.

Ain't it funny how FLIP PHONES are considered retro? My dad was one of the first people in our area to get a tiny Motorola flip phone, the latest model at the time, a marvel of miniaturization. It was slightly larger than a matchbox, and it weighed nothing. A shopping assistant at the local store was so fascinated by it she asked my dad to hold it 🤣. My current flagship phone weighs ca. 230g...

I wanted to ask why K solved to THOU but it just dawned on me. 1k, thousand. Doh. Easy. Why was I confused about it in the first place? I should have my head checked.
You had me at CORGIS, Adrienne. A very lively debut. Congratulations on  publication and condolences on your loss.

Congrats on your debut Adrianne. Impressive puzzle, especially the spans

And condolences on the loss of Arjun. He sounds like the kind of friend everyone should have. I’m sure he’d be so very pleased for you today
This puzzle was a joy to solve! My new Friday best time, and a whole load of fun. Congrats on the debut :)

Congratulations on a fantastic NYT debut, Ms Baik! There are many wonderful answers in your grid. 

Thank you for sharing the story of Arjun. I’m sorry to hear about your loss.

Surprisingly easy, but enjoyable puzzle, since I'm still working on Thursday's.

Though I don't gamble, I guess living in Vegas has rubbed off. My immediate reaction to seeing the clue "Request by those under 21" was HITME.

I enjoyed reading Adrianne's notes, until I got to the gut punch at the end. So sorry for your loss. I know Arjun would have been so proud of you.

So happy to see a Mudder creating such great puzzles!  Congrats on your debut!  Thank you for sharing your memories of Arjun with us, it feels like he would be incredibly proud of you and excited to solve your puzzle.
This was way too easy for a Friday. Hitme was the only clue that really misdirected me

Holy cow!
Constructor Notes never choked me up before today!
Right out of left field, that was...
Great puzzle, fabulous debut!  But why the exclamation point on 27D?  I don’t get it.
26A should be lower caps; the kilo symbol is not in uppercase. Otherwise fun puzzle, easier than I imagined at first glance
Adrianne was the TA for my chem lab last semester; very exciting to see her debut!
Can anyone explain 41 across and 32 down to me. Completed the whole thing and still have no idea how they link to o the clues 🤣

Wow. An incredibly intimidating looking grid that actually produced a fairly smooth fill. Very well done Ms Baik.

Your comments were a real gut punch. I hope you feel you’ve done your friend proud.

With subtle pointers at 17, 44 and 49A you give me hope for your country. Let the next generation take over.

An impressive debut, and a haunting tribute.

From the memoriam reposted earlier in these comments, it is clear that Arjun touched many hearts and lives. And now he has touched ours. Thank you, Adrianne, for sharing not only your talent, but your story as well. I look forward to your next puzzle.
Greenland is DANISH? Let's not get into politics so early in the morning. (sarcasm)
Friday is meant to be the best day of the week... Why ruin it with a puzzle like this

Whew. And Wow! Typical tough Friday workout for me, but it all came together with working the crosses. And... Two grid-spanning triple stacks at the top and bottom of the puzzle. That is just... amazing. Can't even imagine how much work it must take to construct something like that. Looking forward to more from Ms. Baik. I have a feeling we're going to see quite a bit more from here in the future. And of course my puzzle find today. Just kind of a cute Monday from December 20, 2010 by Donna Hoke. Just five theme answers, straightforwardly clued and placed symmetrically at the top and bottom sections and one in the middle. Those answers: CATSCRADLE MONKEYSUNCLE DOGSAGE ELEPHANTSEAR LIONSSHARE Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=12/20/2010&g=60&d=A And here's the link to another quite amazing puzzle by Ms. Hoke: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/14/2007 I'm done. ....
Congratulations, Adrianne and good on you for persisting. Thank you for a most enjoyable puzzle.

So sorry, Adrianne, for the loss of your dear friend Arjun, and thank you for reminding us how powerful our simple kindnesses can be in the lives of others.  You said you hope that sharing his story will inspire.  It greatly moved and inspired me.  Thank you.
Fast Friday. But enjoyable nonetheless. Took less than half my average time. Good debut.
I find long spanners a fun challenge, so of course really enjoyed this one and hope to see more from Adrianne .

Not me crying reading the constructor notes.  I’m so sorry about your friend.

Congratulations on being published!  This is a fun one!

Congratulations on your NYT debut, Adrianne.  

Nice themeless with six fun grid spanning entries.  I loved HIT ME for [Request by those under 21].

Oh - one more puzzle find. A Sunday from January 26, 1986 by Bert Rosenfield with the title "Doubled headers." A lot of theme answers in that one, all straightforwardly clued. Here are some examples: MIRRORMIRRORONTHEWALL OVEROVERTHERE GOINGGOINGGONE REDREDROBIN NEVERNEVERLAND MANYMANYMOONS DODOTHATVOODOOTHATYOU - linked back to one across which (of course) was DOSOWELL. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=1/26/1986&g=29&d=A ....

Dogs on short stumpy legs, long novels, Dante, Barnes & (implied) Noble, and triple-stacked spanners? A puzzle to warm the cockles of my heart. 

As for Adrianne’s story—I’m not crying; you’re crying. 

Adrianne, may your life be filled with friendships like the one you shared with Arjun. I am so sorry for your loss.

Oh, so clean, so noise-free, so well-scrubbed, this filled-in grid.  My whole being calms down as I look it over.  Ahhhh.

But that’s not all I liked.  That top stack, for instance, opening with the lovely colloquial THAT ANSWERS THAT – a NYT answer debut, by the way – then shifting gears to the classy ROYAL OPERA HOUSE, then moving to EVERY VOTE COUNTS, that in ordinary times would sound, well, ordinary, but packs a punch, at least in my mind, these days.  Gorgeous stack.

I liked HOVER floating at the top.  I liked MAIN POINT and can’t believe it has never appeared in a Times crossword before.  I liked CHEATS IN, which so perfectly describes that infielder sneakily edging closer to the batter.  I liked ON INTIMATE TERMS – simply a lovely phrase.

And I loved [Request for those under 21] which had me trying to come up with scenarios involving young people for so long that when the answer finally hit me (as it were), it gave me one terrific aha.

From all this, I left the puzzle feeling happy – what a gift!  Congratulations on your debut, Adrianne, and thank you for this jewel!
Adrianne, congratulations on a great debut puzzle. I really enjoyed it. Condolences on the loss of your friend, I'm sure he would be very proud of you.
I watch 162 baseball games (plus postseason) every year and I’ve never heard “cheats in.”

I'm not usually too effusive, but I thought this was superb. The entries were rock solid, the clues were fresh, it wasn't too easy and wasn't annoying - I just really clicked with this puzzle and enjoyed solving it. Seasoned constructors don't make them as good.
Adrianne is gonna be a star that much is obvious, thanks for the first of many!

Congratulations on your debut!
I’m so sorry about Arjun. I’m sorry you didn’t
get to keep him for much, much longer and 
celebrate this day with him.

Crucivibed like crazy on this one.
Only downside was that I wish I’d been able
to enjoy it for the whole morning,
but it was lovely, fresh and fun.

Looking forward to your next!

Happy Friday all!

Favorite clue: 42 D. Got stuck on age; delighted by answer.

Blush: 37A I went a bit further back in time to flipchart, something I used a lot in my classroom)

Amazing debut.
I really enjoyed this one. 
Retro communication? I was thinking semaphore, Morse code, telegraph ...
Well done.

What a moving story!

Congratulations (and condolences) from an old Sage Hen.

Amazing debut!
Congratulations and please continue to build crossword puzzles and with them, new relationships.
Thirty five plus years into our puzzling relationship, we are still thrilled to hear about relationships formed over crosswords, this seems to be the best way of synchronizing your thoughts with another human being.
Thank you for sharing with all of us

Today I solved my 500th puzzle in a row. And there could be no better crossword for that occasion than this beautiful tribute to a singular friend. Thank you, Ms. Baik. I'm sure Arjun is celebrating somewhere too.

Congratulations on the debut!

A well-constructed puzzle with some nice entries. RACCOONS and LIONSSHARE were especially interesting.

Very easy one for me. Just half-a-minute longer than my fastest Friday ever. As I've indicated many times, large stacks consisting of familiar phrases make puzzles *much easier* for me to solve. Had the top three spanners filled in within two minutes of starting the puzzle, and the three at the bottom took just a bit longer. Spent most of my time in the mid-section of the grid.

Not sure what the reaction to CHEATSIN will be, but this former infielder avers it to be valid and perfectly clued.

Smiled a bit at "Mushroom-to-be" for SPORE. While the clue is fine, its equivalent for flowering plants might be "Fruit-to-be" for SEED. A rather alpha-and-omega sort of clue. (Or perhaps it's omega-and-alpha? Which came first, the mushroom or the SPORE?)

Nice puzzle!
Favorite clue, 49 across. Such an interesting crossword. Congratulations and condolences. Thank you.
Like I said, Fridays and Saturdays are the best puzzles consistently. This one looked impossible until I solved it. More of these please.

So very sorry about your friend. I can empathize having lost several friends at a young age. 

And what a lovely way to honor him. I enjoyed your debut and look forward to many more.

Good luck in school!
Do many cars still have CD SLOTs these days? I can’t remember the last time I saw one! A fun puzzle nevertheless

Small shriek emitted on first seeing the grid, but this felt like an easy Friday for me, despite having to reset my mental accent to discern TROMP, CHOW and SHOOK UP.

Loved the cluing of HIT ME, which I got disconcertingly quickly, though I wouldn't advise it as a general rule. CD SLOT was an "I wish" moment, given that I'm a fan of owning physical media.

Hardest of the spanners was HATERS GONNA HATE, which in my experience is the antithesis of "nonchalant". I find the subtext is most often (but not exclusively), "How DARE you express mild dislike for something I love!" Then again, I don't hate much in life, and what I do I don't share publicly, so I may just have encountered a select group of Mr Angry correspondents.

To the constructor:

Your retelling of your heart-breaking loss made me forget, and then not want to think about, how fun this puzzle was.

But maybe that would miss the crux of today. So:
If you’re idly dreaming, remember to put your pants on first.
:)

Arjun spent the last day of his life being a good fellow. What a sad loss.

This is a great puzzle. Hard, but not in an annoying way, and fun to solve. I enjoyed the 15-square answers, too, which is usually not the case.

(Did anyone else try FLIPCHART before FLIPPHONE?)

Congratulations on the debut, and I’m sorry to hear about your loss. It’s an inspiring story and I was quite moved. I really enjoyed this puzzle, only one second off my Friday PB! I was able to get the north full spanner’s surprisingly quickly, while the south relied on a lot of crosses.
Adrianne, nice job. And, when not creating puzzles or chemical compounds you can reenact "The Swimmer" (John Cheever) via Claremont College's pools. Afterwards you can go to Walters.
A lovely debut. Thsnk you.

I genuinely enjoyed solving today's puzzle, nice job to the constructor. 

4D… I had to research this after the fact to learn it to be loosely based on a geological (feature?). Nicely crafted clue! In Appalachian-American culture, it references a donut-shaped inflatable item required on automobiles, usually in fours.

24D… A  reaction to those who incessantly find subliminal anti-27D messages in the most harmless of crossword puzzles.

27D… A subliminal jab at the car owned by the Duke boys? Generals who don't deserve a place in history? Too soon?

Quite a challenging puzzle, wonderful debut…and congratulations especially on the triple stack. I am so sorry for the loss of your friend and lab partner. I looked up his obituary this morning, and the heart-breaking tributes other students, and professors wrote. He does sound remarkable…it’s clear the world lost a light with his passing. Listening to Chopin’s Ballades as I write this.
Difficult looking puzzle that turned out to be quite easy for a Friday.  Don't quite get CHOW, however.

Really enjoyed this puzzle, esp FLIPPHONE and CDSLOT, both of which I still have and use, among more current devices. There is something so satisfying about actually snapping the phone shut at the end of a call that you just don’t get from a flat phone. 

EVERYVOTECOUNTS felt timely with NYC’s primary just a few days away and early voting going on right now. Someone knocked on my door to talk about one of the candidates yesterday. First time that has happened in my 20-ish years of living here. 

Steve L, happy birthday! Vaer, happy belated birthday!

Adrianne, thank you for a smooth and satisfying themeless puzzle. The clues were fresh, the grid intimidating but surmountable, and the fill made me smile. And thank you for sharing the story of your time with Arjun. Unexpected deaths cause a unique kind of pain, and I’m so sorry you had to experience that. My condolences for the loss of your friend.

Touching constructor notes that can be a useful reminder how valuable encouragement can be. I really enjoyed the misdirection in the clueing here, 27D and 45D being great examples. The smooth solve (which is impressive given those triple stacks!) was only mildly interrupted by some difficulty in coming up with CDSLOT as that feels as retro as 37A!
What a debut! I lit up when I saw the grid, and the puzzle did not disappoint. Thanks for a great start to my weekend Adrianne, best of luck with college!!

🤩 Adrianne, what a spectacular debut. After seeing all of those grid spanners, I decided to solve the downs first. I got ALY, ERE, RACCOONS, TOURS, and HUNG right off the bat. With just those in, I was able to suss out all three of those top spanners, and what a smile it brought 😁 I continued through the grid solving small sections of downs and then seeing if I could do the crosses. Hand up for filling in His before HER and CHeW before CHOW. The latter was my final correction for the gold star 🌟 I was just a couple of minutes over my PB on this one and I really enjoyed it! It just felt fresh and lively. I look forward to solving many more of yours!

On a side note, I was strongly considering attending Harvey Mudd as many of my high school teachers suggested it for me, but I couldn’t bring myself to attend a school that was so close to home (Glendora was a mere 10 miles/three towns away). Best of luck to you as you continue your studies, Adrianne, and I am so sorry for your tragic loss as so many others have expressed here today as well.
WOAH is a spelling I will never accept. Not sure why it annoys me so much lol

I’m always amazed to see a puzzle with (in this case) six 15-letter phrase stacks. How is that even possible?

Maybe there’s software that helps but at some point in history it was done by pure brain power. 

Anyway, really impressive puzzle. Fun clues. I think I was on its wavelength so it only took me 12 minutes but it was a fun 12.

What a nice, puzzle, after some very frustrating ones this week. The grid-spanners looked daunting, but were actually doable once I filled in a few of the Down words. Did not use Wordplay, but an idle glance at the photo helped me with a really puzzling clue. I still didn't get HIT ME, even after filling it in (kept thinking, "The legal drinking age in the US is 21, so... ?"). What a clever misdirection.  

So sorry for your loss.

Great puzzle and debut. 20-across rubbed me the wrong way. Maybe it was the sheer number of them, 30, that was the problem. I know there are terms like “pet owner” and “dog owner” but maybe it’s time to start using “companion” instead. Maybe other species shouldn’t be owned.

Strands #474
“Just a dusting”
🟡🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵🔵🔵

No spoilers until after View All Replies
Very impressive and challenging. All those long phrases and no groaners.

What an excellent puzzle debut, Adrianne!  
Your constructor notes brought tears to my eyes. Arjun would be so proud of your puzzle. 💕

CINDERELLA:
He's a very smart Prince,
He's a Prince who prepares.
Knowing this time I'd run from him,
He spread pitch on the stairs.

-Stephen Sondheim

Because I always misspell the gymnast, I put EVEN I VOTE COUNTS. Kinda like that.

Otherwise a smooth, enjoyable solve.

Congratulations and Condolences, Ms. Baik.
My sleepy Cardigan corgi, Cannoli, gives this puzzle four paws up.
Very enjoyable puzzle!

At least the sailors in the O'Brian and CS Forester Sea NOVELS all say, "AYE, AYE" (note: twice) when they answer the CAP'N--though orders more usually come from his subordinates.
Could some modern tars speak up on this matter?

That bottom triple tier was a bear, IMHO.  WOOF!

I could see NOSH or CHEW for "Munch," but NOT CHOW.  (Yes, I have heard "CHOW down"  but the usage only works *with* DOWN.)  In cookery, to CHOW is to stir-fry, basically, if I remember that cooking show--the one that was erased by disgrace.

I held on to AROMA for the coffee roaster's creation and "What's-HIS-name"  for a long while.

But The Worst Part:  being forced to put in  WOAH.  
Just say WHOA.  Please.


A few years back we rented a VRBO in Gulfport, but found it had issues--a ceiling light fixture that filled up with water after a rain, nonstick cookware-all deeply scratched,  stained bed sheets--which we listed for the owner upon departure.  His response:  "As the wise Taylor Swift says, 'HATERS GONNA HATE.' "  Gag.

Because today is Friday, which to me is an ER volunteer day, I loved seeing it in the puzzle! Loved the shiny new clue for ETSY! A bit of trivia to add to the repertoire! As for MODS, I always forget to post this, but among my other hats, I am a mod on The New York Times Readers Group on Facebook. We are always open to new members! If you are interested, head to https://www.facebook.com/groups/NewYorkTimesReaders and answer the questions, and I'll be happy to add you.

When I saw "Retro means of communication" my first thought (honestly) was "Can and String?" Well, that's just silly. Surely it must be "Telegram" or "Pony Express".
FLIP PHONE???  You're just trying to make me feel old,...
and you succeeded.

Congratulations, young Adrianne Baik on your NYT debut.  Beautiful puzzle.  Your future looks bright!

During Organic Chemistry labs, my partner Stan and I exchanged shoulder rubs. We both became osteopathic doctors to continue such care for others. Decades later when I had Covid in early 2020, he was one of my supports. 
I am so sorry for your loss and the untimely passing of your friend, Arjun.

Your puzzle was marvelous. A+
What a beautiful ode to Arjun! Thank you for a great puzzle and an incredible story to go with it. 🤗

Really good puzzle Adrianne! Loved it! The triple stacks are perfect. As a British-American I am grateful for the Covent Garden gimme and the little Welsh cattle dogs. 
Thinking about CD SLOTS, I wonder how long Car radios will be included?  I’ve been told “Its all computer!”
Casually read the column & was caught off guard by the bonus short story. A well-written surprise tribute that brought tears to my eyes. Thank you for your beautiful sincerity
Loved this one. I rarely solve a Friday but got this one.  A good challenge and was fun to  work through.  Nice!
Interesting to see the opinions on WOAH. "Whoa" is just weird to me, perhaps because "wh-" has a different sound from "w-", and I've never heard the "word" pronounced with a "wh-".
Outstanding Friday, thank you Adrianne for sharing your work!  The six spanners are all excellent.
There should be a word for the precise moment that you figure out that you are enjoying something while you already are enjoying it. Excellent design decisions on this crossword. Well done!

FLIPPHONE, CDSLOT....Whoa, errr I mean uh WOAH...I do feel old!.(Egads, maybe I AM old!)
Thank you, Adrianne, for sharing your story, and for a lovely Friday puzzle.
Oh what a perfect lovely puzzle. Initially daunting but slowly found my way. Can’t wait for more puzzles from this constructor. I’m so sorry to read about your loss.
I'm so sorry to hear about Arjun.

Hi, everyone.  Today, I learned another usage of the word moon!

From MW Dictionary:

moon
2 of 2
verb
mooned; mooning; moons

transitive verb
1
: to spend in idle reverie : dream
—used with away
mooned the afternoon away
2
slang : to expose one's naked buttocks to
One of the boys mooned the crowd.

However, I always thought the definitions were listed by most common usage to rarest usage. Or are slang usages always listed last?  Or perhaps I'm just getting old and no one exposes one's naked buttocks anymore.

@The X-Phile

Whoa and WOAH are actually both a couple of centuries old, according to the Oxford English Dictionary. First citation for whoa from 1801, first for WOAH, ~1790.
Prior to that, there were all sorts of variants like "who" and "whoo" and "whoh".

Those of us who differentiate between wh- and w- are in a minority, so we're used to this sort of thing, but it certainly drives which spelling we favour if a choice is available.
